snippet: The company’s monthly survey, released on Thursday, is meant to complement the Labor Department’s Consumer Price Index, which tracks fewer goods online.
abstract: Adobe's new Digital Price Index, designed as complement to Labor Dept's price index, tracks price of online goods by analyzing millions of online transactions, far more than Labor Dept; Adobe index shows prices of appliances falling 5.7 percent in year to February, compared with 2.7 percent in government's Consumer Price Index equivalent.

byline.original: By HIROKO TABUCHI and KARL RUSSELL

lead_paragraph: The company’s monthly survey, released on Thursday, is meant to complement the Labor Department’s Consumer Price Index, which tracks fewer goods online.

headline.main: It’s Probably Cheaper on the Web, Adobe’s Online Price Index Shows
headline.print_headline: New Price Index Shows Online Is Often Cheaper
